guide.conclusion: The crust on this bread is the best I have ever had: the moistness from the closed container coupled with the relatively intense heat from the base of the pan make a crust that is nice and chewy.

guide.introduction:
Make excellent bread without an oven using only a heavy-based large saucepan, a wooden spoon and a fish slicer or similar.

This method can be adapted to suit your own favourite bread recipe.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Make excellent bread without an oven using only a heavy-based large saucepan, a wooden spoon and a fish slicer or similar.

This method can be adapted to suit your own favourite bread recipe.

Relevant parts
  • Bread readymix
Tools
  • Fish slicer
  • Saucepan
  • Wooden spoon

lines.text: Take 500g of your favourite yeast-based bread readymix and place in a large heavy-based saucepan.
lines.text_raw: Take 500g of your favourite yeast-based bread readymix and place in a large heavy-based saucepan.

lines.text: Add suffcient cold water to make a wettish dough. Make sure you have enough of the readymix to add a little more the following morning. This takes about five minutes.
lines.text_raw: Add suffcient cold water to make a wettish dough. Make sure you have enough of the readymix to add a little more the following morning. This takes about five minutes.

lines.text: After mixing, cover the pan with the lid and keep in a warm place overnight.
lines.text_raw: After mixing, cover the pan with the lid and keep in a warm place overnight.

lines.text: The following morning, add enough of your dry mix to make a soft dough.
lines.text_raw: The following morning, add enough of your dry mix to make a soft dough.

lines.text: Turn out the dough onto a floured worktop and knead until the dough is springy. This should take only a couple of minutes. (How to knead dough)
lines.text_raw: Turn out the dough onto a floured worktop and knead until the dough is springy. This should take only a couple of minutes. ([http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oRoGn-VmlgM|How to knead dough])

lines.text: Clean out the pan, dry thoroughly, and oil the base and sides.
lines.text_raw: Clean out the pan, dry thoroughly, and oil the base and sides.

lines.text: Place the ball of dough into the pan, cover with the lid, and put in a warm place to rise.
lines.text_raw: Place the ball of dough into the pan, cover with the lid, and put in a warm place to rise.

lines.text: When the dough has doubled in size, place the pan with the dough onto a hob ring or stove burner at the highest setting.
lines.text_raw: When the dough has doubled in size, place the pan with the dough onto a hob ring or stove burner at the highest setting.

lines.text: Heat until you can hear the dough starting to fry on the base.
lines.text_raw: Heat until you can hear the dough starting to fry on the base.

lines.text: Keep at the high heat for a couple of minutes. You should aim to get a good colour to your crust at this point.
lines.text_raw: Keep at the high heat for a couple of minutes. You should aim to get a good colour to your crust at this point.

lines.text: Turn the heat down to the lowest setting and leave for about half an hour, letting the condensation drip onto the bread.
lines.text_raw: Turn the heat down to the lowest setting and leave for about half an hour, letting the condensation drip onto the bread.

lines.text: After half an hour has passed, use a fish slicer or similar to carefully turn the loaf over. You may need to tip the pan as you do this to make it easier.
lines.text_raw: After half an hour has passed, use a fish slicer or similar to carefully turn the loaf over. You may need to tip the pan as you do this to make it easier.

lines.text: Turn the heat up to full again just to get the other side to a nice crust.
lines.text_raw: Turn the heat up to full again just to get the other side to a nice crust.

lines.text: Turn down the heat to the minimum again and cook with the lid off until the loaf makes a hollow sound when tapped. I find a further half hour works for me.
lines.text_raw: Turn down the heat to the minimum again and cook with the lid off until the loaf makes a hollow sound when tapped. I find a further half hour works for me.

lines.text: Now that your loaf is cooked, you can turn the heat up a little and cook the sides if you wish, turning the loaf from time to time as you keep a good eye on it so as not to burn the sides.
lines.text_raw: Now that your loaf is cooked, you can turn the heat up a little and cook the sides if you wish, turning the loaf from time to time as you keep a good eye on it so as not to burn the sides.

lines.text: When you have finished the sides turn the loaf out onto a cooling rack and allow to cool thoroughly before slicing.
lines.text_raw: When you have finished the sides turn the loaf out onto a cooling rack and allow to cool thoroughly before slicing.
